**Response:** We believe that hierarchy is unnecessary and not an elegant engineering solution. What the hierarchical structure has done is introduce unnecessary need for more patchwork like suggestions, definitions, and vocabulary proposal which in the end do not address the concerns of the larger ecosystem. We are happy to use whatever language to communicate this with the understanding that Search and AI are synonymous in experience. We do believe that if all or some of the preferences are present simultaneously - there is indeed a logic to break any ties in preference expression that should be considered as part of the attachment mechanism with priority towards the most restrictive preference. Please note that I have provided an example to show how layering is possible without a hierarchy in the vocabulary itself in response to a question below. 

> * Can you explain how you think that "Exact text match" should work?  I don't understand how you would identify what text would need to be quoted as-is from a larger article.  I wasn't able to work out what you meant from the SF Chronicle example either.
**Response:** The “exact text match” category expresses a preference that limits the use of the indicated text content in any outputs to match exactly the source from which that text was retrieved for that instance. It addresses multiple concerns that content owners have expressed and offers much more control in an elegant way. We did not talk at all about the attachment mechanism in our proposal. However, “exact text match” is an elegant engineering solution that does not get into unnecessary issues of how AI ops and workflows are implemented in the background and simply treats the issues that users and content owners raise. We are happy to propose an appropriate attachment mechanism. Furthermore, the request to not transform text, verbs, sentences was expressed by various persons in IETF meetings including Matt Rogerson. Second, existing technology which has not yet been optimized for such restrictions is already able to deliver such summarized view of documents, detecting the dominant key sentences listed in the document. Please try in your favorite AI solution the following: “_Generate a summary from <URL> quoting only key sentences of the document._” 

> * I'm not clear on whether you believe the statements people might make using this proposed vocabulary to be preferences in the sense that they might be ignored.  I can't tell whether the removal of the text on that was for brevity (as you do with boilerplate) or to make a specific point.  It seems like the goal is to make compliance with each of the proposed "directives" is now measurable, which might argue for something stricter.
**Response:** We intend for our proposal to be included into the context of the current drafts – not totally usurp it. We understand these are preferences – but, we prefer to use a display-based preference. We did not have a better way to provide a focused proposal in response to the WGLC. So – this is just for logistics and keeping the focus on our display-based preferences vocabulary.  

> One thing that might help people understand this better is to walk through a couple of scenarios and see how the new approach might affect a different outcome. I certainly found the examples you included in the appendix to be helpful, but they seemed somewhat search-centric and they were somewhat mechanical (that might be the point, in which case it would be good to confirm that).
**Response:** We welcome the opportunity to present additional scenarios and intend to share - leading up to Zurich. We appreciate that our experience with these and similar controls stems from significant background in operating a search engine, yet these controls apply more broadly. The definitions do not include a restriction to Search or some other experience. The examples tease out what we think are the use cases that have been subject to much debate over the last several months – namely, how publisher content is presented, irrespective of the interface. We do not see search and AI as distinct. Search is AI and the experiences are not distinguishable. 

> The hot question of the moment seems to be how AI overviews might be affected; answering that would be helpful. We've also talked about a few things including how this might affect a generative image creation tool for style or composition mimickry. I understand that that's more words, which can distract from a core message, but it's potentially useful supplemental material that will help illustrate utility.
**Response:** While this debate may look hot today – this is too specific to one form of many such experiences. The “Exact text match” category is clearly one way to ensure the content is not changed and presented as a summarization. This coupled with “display length” can provide an elegant solution.￼ Please also note that there are current very well-known options such as “_data-nosnippet”_ that clearly offer another elegant way of dealing with this scenario – particularly in the context of content that may be partially paywalled. It is common practice to enclose such content using the “_data-nosnippet_” option. 

> Finally, I want to understand how you see the proposal better at a high level. Should I look at this as a single change that has to be taken in its entirety or not at all? Or, are each of the above targeted changes things that you could argue for independently, such that we could break this down and discuss each in turn?
**Response:** The display-based proposal vocabulary is designed to be logical and allows layering. We think that they work well together as a set. For example, the “exact text match” preference can co-exist with a “display text length” preference which will limit the number of words that are matched to the length indicated. We believe that we truly are being responsive to the larger community. Once people spend time to understand what we are proposing, I think it will be a lot easier. As you point out below – we are open to a discussion on what kind of breakdown may make sense without losing the engineering integrity of what we are proposing. 

> Obviously, breaking things down might make organizing discussion easier, but that only makes sense if there isn't an overarching principle that might motivate making all the changes together. It seems like you are seeking to articulate a principle at a higher level, but I'm struggling to grasp it. I don't know if that is what you are getting at with the concept of "display-based preferences", which I admit I had a lot of trouble with. Maybe it's a search thing I should be familiar with, but missed. Is there a framing you would use for the current drafts that I could use as a point of comparison that would help me better contrast the approaches? Or something else that might help me internalize this "display-based preference" concept?
**Response:** The current draft really attempts to be a very broad vehicle covering every possible scenario. This is its critical flaw. Instead, we are much narrowly focused on bypassing a long-winded debate about terms like “Automated Processing” and instead focus on a solution that has longevity and addresses the point at which an output is generated. We view ai-preferences as a true enablement mechanism that can be easily understood by all and build on extant practices.  We are happy to help build illustrative examples and/or work with you to craft a narrative to move the draft forward.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
I wrote this in email but adding here as well...

It's an interesting proposal, Krishna, but it is only focused on web crawlers - and not on the myriad of other ways in which context can be obtained - and then potentially used in ways where the preferences need to be evaluated.  It also assumes that all content will be presented online and/or in a web browser/UA - again limiting.

If you were to revise the proposal to be agnostic to how content is obtained, processed and presented - it might be more viable as an alternative to the current Vocab proposal (which is agnostic).

issues.title: Proposal to add a Substitutive Use Category to the Vocab Doc
issues.author: BradSilver99
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

Note:  this issue mirrors the proposal made in this I-D here:  https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-silver-aipref-vocab-substitutive/ 

This proposal aims to address a material gap in the Vocabulary document.  This gap renders the proposal incomplete but also potentially harmful to the interests of right holders who may be unable to specifically express a preference regarding the summarization/stylistic simulation of their content.  This category is an essential companion to the search category, given the broad adoption of summarization approaches by existing search engines as well most other LLMs.  

**Issue Description**:
Existing mechanisms for expressing preferences in the Vocabulary Document do not address concerns which
have been strongly articulated about the practice of using digital assets as input to AI models to generate outputs which substitute for or undermine the value of the original assets.  This gap leaves a broad group of stakeholders (including creators, journalists and publishers) without a means to express a preference for a type of use which is already having a material adverse impact on their rights.  Developers and deployers of AI systems are also left without a clear, standardized preference signal regarding such uses, which results in "blunt" approaches to gathering such content - exposing them to legal risk.  This proposal is for the addition of a category in the Vocabulary document to define a tailored preference category to address the specific need, improve visibility across the board and support continued broad access to information and content.

The use of digital assets for inferencing "in real time" is widespread as a means of improving the accuracy and contextual relevance of outputs, such as through the use of techniques such as Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).  The flipside of that value is that such outputs are inclined to substitute for or dilute the value of the original asset, which decreases user engagement with the original asset.  This harms revenue opportunities and undermines the ability of the owner or distributor of the original asset to connect directly with their intended audience.  For example, the use of journalistic material to create AI-generated summaries which have resulted in the substantial reduction of internet traffic to online publications.  In the longer term, this jeopardises the sustainability of those enterprises and the underlying incentives to create and publish such material.  To mitigate this, some are moving content behind paywalls and deploying other means of limiting open access - diminishing access to information and content.

Should incentives to create diminish, AI innovation will also suffer as a result of less quality content on which to build a distribution funnel.  This would also undermine the sustainability and verifiability of news and information services relied upon by the public and government institutions.  Where the AI model or platform takes on the role of information gatekeeper and shaper, connections between the public and original sources can be severed (or warped), which undermines the ability and willingness of internet users to ensure what they are reading, hearing or watching matches the original source(s), allowing factual misrepresentations to propagate and go unchecked.

Creators have also justifiably expressed the need for a preference that addresses the use of their assets to create derivative works "in the style of" such original assets.  Creators are harmed by the unfettered use of their works as inputs to AI Models to create outputs which dilute the market for their works, adopting distinctive elements and styles established by the creators themselves - which also harms their moral rights and interests to protect the integrity of their works and ensure attribution.

  Insertion of new category:  **AI Substitutive Use Category** 

   The Act of using one or more assets as input to a trained AI/ML model
   (as opposed to the training of the model) which results in an output
   which incorporates, summarizes, aggregates or reproduces the assets,
   including stylistic elements thereof; provided, however that this
   category does not cover the use of a lawfully acquired digital asset
   where carried out directly by an end user (as opposed to a search
   application or bot) as input to a trained model to create a summary
   of such digital asset.

   The use of assets for AI Substitutive Use is a proper subset of
   Automated Processing usage [AIPREF-VOCAB].

   This category is distinct from AI Training or Generative AI Training,
   as it addresses uses that occur after a model has been trained,
   during inference.  It is also distinct from Search, which covers uses
   that direct users back to the original asset.  Substitutive Use, by
   contrast, describes outputs that replace, reduce the utility of, or
   make the source asset redundant to users by summarizing, reproducing,
   or restyling its contents.

   Consistent with that objective, this category would not apply where
   end users are summarising digital assets which they have already
   acquired, outside of the context of search or retrieving such assets
   from online locations in summarized form.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Definition of AI
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

S 2.

      Artificial Intelligence (AI):
      An engineered system of sufficient complexity that, for a given
      set of human-defined objectives, learns from data to generate
      outputs such as content, predictions, recommendations, or
      decisions.

As I mentioned previously, I think this definition of AI is extremely
problematic and would effectively sweep in any statistical
technique. I understand that "sufficient complexity" is intended to
somehow reduce the scope, but it's a totally subjective standard.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Use of 'Machine Learning'
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

      AI Training:
        The application of machine learning to data to produce or improve
        a model for an artificial intelligence system.

I'm not sure what "machine learning" is doing here.

### Proposed Resolution

I'm not sure what "machine learning" is doing here. Why not just:

      The use of data to produce or improve an artificial
      intelligence system.

I would then strike the term "machine learning" entirely.

issues.title: Difference between "unknown" and "allowed"
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

S 3.

    After processing a statement of preferences the recipient associates
    each category of use one of three preference values: "allowed",
    "disallowed", or "unknown".  In the absence of a statement of
    preference, all usage categories are assigned a preference value of
    "unknown".

What's the semnatic difference between "unknown" and "allowed"?
Eventually, I need to either use or not use a given piece of
data. Is this just an internal detail of the algorithm?

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Defaults
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

S 5.

    One approach for dealing with an "unknown" outcome is to assign a
    default value.  This document takes no position on what default might
    be assigned.

I don't think this makes any sense. The purpose of this document
is to allow the processing agent to understand the declaring
party's preferences, and we don't even require the agent
to respect them, so it's weird to talk about defaults in
that context.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

comments.author: mcerdancch-png
comments.body:
Regarding defaults, I suggest that the vocabulary should promote accessibility-friendly defaults, especially for people with cognitive and learning disabilities.

When no explicit preference is provided, the system should fall back to defaults that reduce cognitive load  e.g. clear/simple text, predictable navigation, and visual supports. This avoids situations where lack of preference leads to inaccessible or overwhelming outputs.

In my applied research (Decàleg per a l’atenció al públic amb TEA, Cerdan-Chiscano, 2023, Diputació de Barcelona & Aprenem Autisme), one of the key findings is that defaults matter: providing simple explanations, clear documents, and advance information is essential to avoid communication breakdown.

I therefore recommend that the draft explicitly states that defaults should favour accessibility and usability, with cognitive accessibility as a key dimension.

issues.title: Automated Processing is too broad
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

As I and others have noted, "automated processing" essentially
sweeps in any web crawler. In particular, as noted by Greg Lindahl,
parsing the document to find links is plainly "automated
processing", so you just can't really have a crawler without
"automated processing", which makes this whole category redundant
with forbidding crawling in the existing robots.txt framework.


### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

comments.author: TimidRobot
comments.body:
See also [[ai-control] AI Processing - a more focused top category?](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/YQA1sJUZncVXqKQS4Uw1zuePv1I/) (markdown formatting added for clarity):
> I wonder if replacing "Automated Processing" (`all`) with "AI Processing"
> (`all-ai`) would help to increase the accuracy of the vocabulary without
> hindering its effectiveness. I think this change might reduce the chance of
> unintended consequences while keeping the essential function.
>
> ## Current text:
>
>> ### 4.1. Automated Processing Category
>>
>> The act of using automated processing on one or more assets to analyze text
>> and data in order to generate information which includes but is not limited
>> to patterns, trends and correlations.
>>
>> The use of assets for automated processing encompasses all the subsequent
>> categories.
>
>
> ## Proposed text:
>
>> ### 4.1. AI Processing Category
>>
>> The act of using AI processing on one or more assets to analyze text and
>> data in order to generate information which includes but is not limited to
>> patterns, trends and correlations.
>
> The use of assets for AI processing encompasses all the subsequent
> categories.

comments.author: felixreda
comments.body: The proposal by @TimidRobot at least has the distinct advantage of bringing the overarching category within the scope of the Charter. As it stands, Automated Processing would cover a lot of uses that cannot be subsumed under "how content is collected and processed for Artificial Intelligence (AI) model development, deployment, and use". That said, it would make the issue of landing on a clear definition of AI more urgent.

comments.author: Jo-Levy
comments.body: The category described by 4.1, automated processing, is not only overly broad, it is also not applied consistently with the other categories, train-ai and train-genai. These categories do not describe what is done to the digital content -- the describe the end purpose for which the digital content is being used. They are expressing a preference for their content to be used (or not) to train ai or to be used (or not) to train genai. The preference could apply to content being used by humans to train AI by an algorithm or by a simply computer program.  By contrast,the " automated processing" category does not describe or limit itself to the purpose of the processing --it simply expresses a preference based on the means by which data is "processed".  It is not even limited to processing after the data has been collected from the website, which is inconsistent with the many discussions on limiting the vocabulary to usage of content.  The category should be removed.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
_Also from @chrisn in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/2ZbEx73js_cTQT8mI1Wy6_0ZC_s):_

The scope, set out in the Abstract and Introduction, "a vocabulary of preferences regarding how automated systems process digital assets" seems overly broad. As a publisher the usage I'm most concerned about is processing in AI systems, and in particular generative AI. Introducing a scope for all automated systems risks unintended consequences for other uses that are unrelated to AI. So I suggest more clearly scoping the document to AI related usage.

Following from the above, the Automated Processing Category defined in Section 4.1 should either be revised (the original Text and Data Mining was preferable, because it's more specific) or removed entirely.

issues.title: Search's Parent
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

I don't understand why "search" is somehow a subset of "automated
processing" rather than "AI training". In many if not most cases,
search will involve training an AI model, especially given the very
wide parameters of "AI" (see below).

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: AI Training and Generative AI Training are Too Broad
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

AI training is a coherent category but seems like a trap for the
unwary, because a lot of people are going to turn it on and thus
exclude all kinds of useful applications, when what they really want
is much more narrow (something like gen AI). I also have a problem
with the term "training" for the reasons indicated above.

Generative AI training is a remarkably wide category (see
aforementioned comments about substitution, summarization, and
generating original content).


### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Bots Collect Data for Multiple Purposes
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

As an aside, it's obviously possible for a bot to collect data for
multiple purposes. Maybe I've missed it, but does this draft say what
the rules are there? I guess you're supposed to somehow only proceed
if the intersection of all the uses is allowed? S 5.1 seems to be
about the related but different problem of harmonizing multiple
statements for a given usage.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Overall approach of the Vocabulary
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_Raised in [email by EKR](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/dxpLCD7R2L-L07fEQCITjXjUcMY)_

I don't think this taxonomy is really going in the right direction. I
have some critiques of the specific categories but, more broadly, I
think this is tied to specific technology choices in a way that's
unlikely to age well. I think instead it would be much more useful to
focus on the uses to which the data will be put (i.e., the output of the model),
as that's really the source of unhappiness about these systems.

Just so we're on the same page modern LLMs work (very approximately)
by training on an enormous corpus of data which sets the model weights
(I'm deliberately conflating pre-training and fine-tuning).  They are
then prompted with input and asked to create output based on that
input, as well as the output it's already generated (collectively the
context). As part of that process, some models can also collect new
data and use that as part of the context (RAG). In the context of web
crawling, then we have two ways for data to get into the system:

- In the training phase and stored in the model weights.
- In the generation phase as part of the context via RAG.

This is an important technical distinction, but it's not clear why it
matters from the perspective of the site. Consider an AI system which
collects the same corpus as is currently used for pre-training but
only trains on a small portion of it and then when it's asked to
generate content, uses some kind of "internal RAG" to suck in the
relevant documents and generate the output (this is a lot more like
human brains seem to work in my experience, because we just can't
remember much stuff). From the perspective of the site this is the
same: the system is using the site's content to generate new content,
but in the taxonomy of this draft, this isn't AI training or even
generative AI training because it doesn't impact the model
weights. Obviously I have no idea if this is a productive technical
direction, but neither do you, and conformance shouldn't hinge
on whether it turns out to be.

In my opinion a much more productive direction would be to focus on
the application to which this data is being put.  I don't have
anything like a complete story, but it seems to me that we have some
understanding of the categories at either end of the spectrum:

- Indexing (search): where you attempt to determine which
  piece of content the user wants and steer them towards it.

- Substitution: where the service generates something that
  is effectively a substitute good for the content.

I think these are useful conceptually because the first is the
traditional one that I think people have generally accepted as "good"
and the second is the one that seems to be of most concern. Obviously,
it's not as clear as that because even before generative AI search
systems were producing substitute goods (infoboxes, etc.), but I think
that's a feature of this analysis, because sites often didn't like
that and I think this kind of taxonomy captures that intuition without
worrying about whether the substitute good was generated via some
LLM, deterministic hand-written code, or something in between.

In between these two, we have some other applications. For instance:

- Summarization (think AI overviews) this is a partial substitute, but
  often it comes with a source link which can steer traffic to the
  site.

- Generating original content that isn't a direct substitute.  An
  example here might be code generation: the other day I asked an AI
  to help write me a scraper for the IETF agenda [0] and while I'm
  sure it was inspired by a lot of existing scraping scripts, it's not
  like it plagiarized one of them in total or somehow reduced the
  demand for them (this is a distinct question from whether it
  injected some verbatim code).

Again, I don't claim that these are the right dividing lines, but I
think that this kind of analysis does a better job of capturing what
is actually concerning to sites about AI. The challenge then becomes
how to turn these into relatively precise definitions. This is
probably harder than the current definitions, but I don't think
precision is a virtue if the definitions aren't actually a good fit to
the problem they are trying to solve (as they say, "for every complex
problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong").

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: 3.2 Respecting Preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

Per thread on the list, there is still contention about the text in 3.2.


### Proposed Resolution

_Sourced from e-mail by [Alissa](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/5vUslBkhFk-na7geaO_XFaWqc0c)_

1. Getting rid of the normative MAY. I know this was discussed on the PR thread before the -03 was published. This whole section is in the realm of non-technical considerations and using a normative keyword muddies that.

2.  Significantly paring back the text starting from “Usage preferences can be ignored …” so that it provides less fodder for future debate about what was really intended here. I have a suggestion below that echoes back to Lila’s original note about historic, widespread use of certain tools. I nixed “free expression” from the list as it felt like the everything category, but I think including the other examples is helpfully illustrative.

> Parties might choose not to honor preferences they receive on the basis of express agreements they have with other parties, for legal compliance purposes, or for other reasons. Historically, entities engaged in automated processing of digital assets in support of safety, education, scholarship, research, preservation, interoperability, accessibility, and other priorities have needed to make such choices in response to existing preference signaling mechanisms, and affected parties have had to grapple with the consequences. The preference statements described in this specification are no different.

comments.author: mcerdancch-png
comments.body:
I would like to highlight the importance of explicitly including cognitive accessibility preferences within this section.

People with cognitive and learning disabilities often need preferences such as:
– simplified or plain language,
– anticipation of steps in a process,
– additional response time,
– support with visual aids (icons, pictograms, real images).

These preferences must be respected in the same way as security or privacy preferences, because they directly affect users’ ability to interact with AI systems.

As an example, my research with public administrations in Barcelona resulted in a set of practical communication guidelines (Decàleg per a l’atenció al públic amb TEA, Cerdan-Chiscano, 2023, Diputació de Barcelona & Aprenem Autisme, available at: [ResearchGate link](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/395700660_Decaleg_pautes_atencio_al_public_amb_TEA)
). These show how respecting such preferences significantly improves usability for autistic people and others with cognitive disabilities.

I recommend extending the vocabulary to allow explicit declaration of cognitive accessibility preferences, so that systems are required to respect them.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
_From @chrisn in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/2ZbEx73js_cTQT8mI1Wy6_0ZC_s):_

The list of examples in Section 3.2 of cases where preferences could be ignored, should be removed. The preceding paragraph in this section makes clear the considerations where preferences could be ignored, and the specification should not attempt to define or identify specific examples. This should be left to policymakers, and it may vary by legal jurisdiction.

issues.title: Removal of "bots" from Vocab Section 6.1
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

See Jlevy comment from 9/14   re the ambiguity, confusion, and potential  inaccurate overlap with the term "bots" in Section 6.1  as used in other IETF WG documents/charters:  

 I have searched the entire thread archive, but do not see any discussion regarding the use of the term “bots.”   

The other terms in 6.1 describe how the data is used, e.g. to “train” or “search.” But the term “bots” suggests it is based on who is using the data, rather than what is being done to the data. For example, in the WebBotAuthN Working Group, the term “bots” is  used to refer to “non-browser clients.” By using the term “bots” in Section 6.1, it creates an inconsistent approach that will lead to confusion about the meaning of the preference. Some people may incorrectly believe that bots=n is a preference to disallow access by bots. Others may incorrectly believe bots=n is a preference to disallow all use by bots, regardless of whether that use is for or related to AI. 

This is especially important because the Vocab and Attach documents are not intended to be read together all the time.  The Vocab is intended to also be a standalone document. As I understand it, members of this group are liaising with other standards bodies to export the final language from this document to other bodies for their use independently, without the structure of the Attach document or robots.txt.  See, for example, Leonard’s recent email stating: <<This vocab is designed to be used in any scenario - online or offline, web or otherwise - where someone wishes to express a preference about the AI usage of an asset.>>   Earlier drafts also called for the Vocabulary to “standardize building blocks” that could be used regardless of the manner of attachment. 

When the categories and descriptions in the Vocab document are considered as standalone expressions, it is even more important that their scope and intent is clear.

Proposal: delete the top category and the accompanying “bots” descriptor in 6.1.  This removes the ambiguity and confusion, maintaining the focus on AI and moving the group more toward consensus.

 See also PKeller reply 9/14 agreeing that the term "clearly also problematic" and suggesting focusing first on the automated processing category (which makes sense).

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

issues.title: Removing normative language: respect, ignore
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

As raised in 8/25 Jlevy comment and subsequent discussions, the language and terminology embedded throughouth is normatively charged and inaccurately attributes human intentions/emotions into this vocabulary, which by its nature is directed at computer programs or algorithms.   Throughout the Vocab document, the words "respect" and "ignore" should be changed to "follow" or "not follow" preference expresssions or intructions.   


### Proposed Resolution

Solution:  In 3.2, 
-change "whether preferences are actually respected during data processing"  to "whether preferencdesare actually followed during data processing."
 - change "An entity that receives usage preferences MAY choose to respect those preferences..." to "An entity that receives usage preferences MAY choose to follow those preferences.
-change "ignored" to "not followed", "ignoring" to "not following" and "ignore" to "not follow" throughout 3.2

issues.title: Replacing: "digital assets" with "digital content"
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

The term "digital asset" is used throughout the Vocab document.  It is confusing and misleading.  A "digital asset" generally and commonly refers to cryptocurrency. The United States Internal Revenue Service (IRS) defines it as "any digital representation of value on a cryptographically secured, distributed ledger (blockchain) or similar technology."  See https://www.irs.gov/filing/digital-assets#description.  
 It's not a term used in robots.txt or the Attach documet which uses the term "content" and "content-usage." A preferable term would be "Digital Content."

### Proposed Resolution

Replace "digital asset" or "digital assets" with "digital content." Replace "asset" with "digital content." Replace "one or more assets" with "digital content." There are 23 instances of the term asset or assets throughout the document.  By using "digital content" there is also no new for a definition of the term "Digital Asset."

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
On the other hand, @Jo-Levy - standards such as C2PA and JPEG Trust both use the term "asset" or "media asset" to differentiate the entire entity/file from just the "content" - in that there exists other parts (e.g. metadata) of an "asset" beyond just the content.

See https://spec.c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.2/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#_assets_and_content and https://ds.jpeg.org/documents/jpegtrust/wg1n100972-105-REQ-Terms_and_definitions_for_JPEG_Trust_v2_0.pdf

comments.author: chrisn
comments.body: I agree with @lrosenthol, asset is a recognised term, so I see no need for change here. There's a clear definition in the Conventions and Definitions section of the draft.

issues.title: Removal of 3.1 Conformance- out of scope
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

Section 3.1 titled Conformance states that an implentation is conformant to the specifications if it correctly follows all normative requirements that apply to it.  This pertains to enforcement, which is out of scope for the Vocab and Attach document. It adds nothing to the Vocabulary or statement of preference. Solution: Delete 3.1 Conformance.

### Proposed Resolution

Delete Section 3.1 Conformance.

comments.author: chrisn
comments.body: I strongly disagree with removing this.

issues.title: Attach Document: Abstract: Remove reference to "consumed by automated systems"
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

 In the abstract,  the phrase “Content creators and other stakeholders might wish to signal their preferences about how their content might be consumed by automated systems” is confusing and does not accurately describe the scope. The preference is not about how  content is consumed from the website.  The preference is about how it is  used after it is accessed or consumed. Also, the phrase "automated systems" is overly broad, particularly since here it seems to refer to crawlers but later it seems to refer to AI systems that need to read the preferences after it is collected. This will lead to confusion.

Suggestion:  change to "about whether website content that is accessed orconsumed by crawlers may later be used to train or develop AI models."


### Proposed Resolution

Suggestion:  change to "about whether website content that is accessed orconsumed by crawlers may later be used to train or develop AI mode

issues.title: Attach Document:  Add non-enforceability provision similar to what is in the Vocab document
issues.author: Jo-Levy
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

Both robots.txt and the Vocab document have language clarifying that the documents do not include enforcement mechanisms.  The Attach document is not. Propose adding  non-enforcement provision similar to Vocab document.

### Proposed Resolution

Suggest adding new Section with non-enforceability language: 
 Non-Enforceability.   This specification is not enforceable.  An entity that receives content usage preferences MAY choose whether or not to follow the preferences.  Many factors may be considered in determining whether to follow a preference, including but not limited to  how the usage corresponds to the usage categories where preferences have been expressed, the type of content, the identity and authority of the Declarant to assert a preference over the specified content, the applicable legal context, or other considerations such as free expression, safety, education, scholarship, research, preservation, interoperability, and accessibility.

issues.title: Distinguishing access and use
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

I'm going to quote @coopdanger here, because her formulation of the issue is pretty good.  I will follow up with a nit on the details, but that doesn't diminish the value of the feedback:

> This raises the question of whether the vocabulary is only meant to be used to express preferences about usage and not initial access regardless of the attachment mechanism. The very first sentence of the vocab doc uses the ambiguous term “processing” while most of the rest of the doc uses “usage.” If the intent is to define a vocabulary that only expresses preferences about an asset after the asset has been obtained (by whatever means), it needs an explicit scoping limitation to that effect. And then every attachment mechanism that gets defined in the IETF or elsewhere needs to reflect that.
>
> Making this distinction explicit might be a simple resolution to some of the concerns that have been raised about the automated processing category, because it would make clear that it’s unnecessary to resolve the question of whether crawling/accessing a site is itself considered automated processing. No preferences are being expressed about access, other than insofar as sites would expect crawlers not to crawl their site if the site wishes to disallow all the uses of interest to the crawler. It would not resolve the concerns about behavior habituation and misinterpretation, though.
>
> Even with this distinction made explicit, there would still be the possibility of basically nonsensical use cases, e.g.:
>
> ```http
> User-Agent: *
> Content-Usage: /foo bots=n
> ```
> 
> Like what is the point of allowing crawling/access but then disallowing all usage? Maybe there is a use case I’m missing.
>
> Note also that it may be entirely unrealistic to say that everywhere an attachment mechanism is specified, it has to preserve this distinction between access and usage. It’s not like we can constrain mechanisms that get defined elsewhere.
> 
> I’ve never really been convinced of the need for the top-level category, but if we are going to have one we need to be clear about when it applies, and clarifying that it only applies after an asset has been obtained might help mitigate concerns about its breadth.

### Proposed Resolution

There was some effort to make this distinction in editing, but it's clear that we need to be much clearer about it throughout.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
The very pedantic nit...

The example probably needs an `Allow: /foo` line.  RFC 9309 is not clear when it comes to delineating groups, particularly when it comes to extensions like this one.  That means that a group with no Allow or Disallow lines might be joined to the next group.  That is, this might be one or two groups:

```
User-Agent: *
Content-Usage: /foo bots=n
User-Agent: bar
Content-Usage: /foo bots=y
```

The more substantive point is with respect to this:

> Like what is the point of allowing crawling/access but then disallowing all usage? Maybe there is a use case I’m missing.

As we have discussed at some length, these are preferences and so crawled content that has an associated preference that it not be used for any purpose is still available for use in cases where there is a reason to ignore preferences.

> Note also that it may be entirely unrealistic to say that everywhere an attachment mechanism is specified, it has to preserve this distinction between access and usage. It’s not like we can constrain mechanisms that get defined elsewhere.

I don't think that this is unrealistic.  Getting the bits and using them are distinct actions.  Consider where the preferences are carried in an HTTP header.  It's not like the response isn't delivered and available, even if the preferences indicate that the reason for making the request goes against the stated preferences.  This distinction recognizes that there are still cases where the use motivates (or justifies) ignoring the preference.

issues.title: Attachment: Section 2 preservation of HTTP request header "MUST" is too strong
issues.author: bnewbold
issues.body:
I think this is a couple days late for the formal WGLC, but hope it is helpful to file this here as an issue ahead of the upcoming meeting. I can also take this to the list if prefered.

### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

Section 2 of the Attachment draft has a new section about retaining the `Content-Usage` header from requests, and re-using them on responses for the same content later:

> Servers MUST retain any preferences associated with a request if the content of that request is used to answer later requests. For example, the content of a PUT request that is used to answer subsequent GET requests. Note that servers that have not been updated to understand this field will not comply with this requirement.

I think having the server retain the preference metadata is a great idea, but making it a "MUST" for any server which implements usage preferences is too restrictive. I believe servers should be allowed (and encouraged) to include this metadata header even if they don't have the means to implement state persistence based on request headers. Servers might implement alternative or more ergonomic mechanisms for expressing preferences, for instance via an HTML form field, and that is fine.

### Proposed Resolution

Make it "MAY".

Overall I think this should be more of a recommendation or best practice. Given that I would defer to the editors in terms of how best to phrase things.

issues.title: Automated Processing category risks jeopardizing a safe and working internet
issues.author: kmadhavan-msft
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

The current definition of “automated processing” is broad and ambiguous, encompassing routine functions like exporting to PDF, printing, or viewing content in a browser. As noted by Greg in the working group, even basic link extraction could fall under this category, potentially rendering all crawlers—including non-AI ones—inoperable. 

We’re concerned this framing could unintentionally undermine essential Internet functions such as content moderation, spam filtering, and accessibility features. While we recognize these outcomes are not the intent, the risk remains that critical functionality may be impaired, user expectations misaligned, and implementers exposed to complaints—especially in regulated contexts. 

It’s also worth noting that existing mechanisms already allow publishers to signal bot access preferences. If there are concerns about their adoption or effectiveness, that may be a more productive area for discussion—one we haven’t yet seen raised in this group. 

### Proposed Resolution

Remove the automated processing category. We believe that the Automated Processing category is too broad and vague and will lead to a less safe and open  and open Internet in the long run.

issues.title: Hierarchical structure is problematic and introduces unnecessary complexity
issues.author: kmadhavan-msft
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

The hierarchical structure in vocab-03 -  placing categories like Automated Processing, Search, and AI Training in parent–child relationships - introduces complexity without real benefit. In practice, preferences can be expressed directly on each activity, so the hierarchy does not add clarity; instead it forces artificial nesting. Real-world processing often overlaps across categories, and the hierarchy has already led to a patchwork of overlapping or conflicting proposals. Because publishers simply want to state “allow” or “disallow” for specific uses or use multiple preferences, the extra layer of hierarchy is unnecessary and risks confusing both implementers and publishers. A flatter, modular vocabulary would make preferences easier to understand, more consistent to apply, and better aligned with real systems. 

### Proposed Resolution

Remove the heirarchical structure and replace with a flatter, modular structure that would make the preferences easier to understand, more consistent to apply, and better aligned with real systems.

issues.title: Search should be removed and replaced with display-based preferences
issues.author: kmadhavan-msft
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing WLGC issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen%20label%3Awglc) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

The term “Search” is well understood by webmasters, but using it without a clear definition may cause confusion rather than helping address publisher concerns about display-based approaches. Yet, many challenges arise when attempting to strike a durable definition: 

The line between search and AI is increasingly blurred, making it hard to separate them meaningfully in policy. 

Modern search relies on AI for functions like ranking and snippets, so a distinct “search” opt-out may not be practical. 

The current “search” category appears to regulate internal system behavior in ways that are hard to define or audit. 

Existing mechanisms like robots.txt and noindex already give site owners strong control, so adding a new “search” category could duplicate or conflict with these mechanisms. 

### Proposed Resolution

We have proposed alternate solution detailed here: [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-madhavan-aipref-displaybasedpref-01](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-madhavan-aipref-displaybasedpref-01 )

issues.title: Missing Category for RAG and Grounding
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_From @chrisn in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/2ZbEx73js_cTQT8mI1Wy6_0ZC_s):_

Without a category that covers RAG and grounding usage, the vocabulary does not meet publisher needs. This need was raised at the outset of this work, in the IAB workshop in Washington DC in 2024, and included in the WG charter scope.

In addition to reducing web traffic to original content, such usage introduces the possibility of creating misleading or biased statements, an issue that impacts news publishers in particular, risking undermining their credibility. Research published by the BBC goes into this in more detail, demonstrating that AI-generated answers summarise and present content in a way that can introduce factual inaccuracies and biases that are not present in the original published content.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
_From Bradley Silver in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/zaXD4Ah5ruMVIr1sbdwMVeYkOIk):_

I strongly believe that a post-training/RAG category can't be left to future work - it needs to be part of the baseline framework which this document is attempting to outline.  The need and the prevalence of this activity is too broad to ignore, as are linkages to search as well as training.  I think it would be good to flesh out the concerns expressed by others about over-breadth and make a good faith attempt to see if this can be addressed in the drafting.

comments.author: chrisn
comments.body: I wonder if a way forward here is to re-introduce a RAG / grounding / post-training / inference time usage category, but then focus on the list of 3.2 of where preferences may reasonably be ignored (e.g., the fourth bullet covers detecting harmful content). Taking this approach could address the concerns raised about the search category in #173.

issues.title: Search is too Broad
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_From @chrisn in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/2ZbEx73js_cTQT8mI1Wy6_0ZC_s):_

While I appreciate the effort that has gone into crafting this definition, as it stands it still allows all the generative AI usage that publishers find problematic. If adopted, publishers will be in the position of having to allow the Search Category, because they cannot realistically opt-out of traditional (i.e., non generative AI search).

Given that major search engines are rapidly integrating generative AI features, a generative AI response to a user query that includes links provided via RAG or grounding could be interpreted as "directs users to the location from which the assets were retrieved". The qualifying statements: "Only those parts of applications that direct users to the location of an asset are included in this category of use. This includes the use of titles or excerpts from assets that are used to help users select between multiple candidate options" don't address this concern. The same applies to "Parts of applications that do not direct users to the location of assets, such as summaries, are not covered by this category of use", because search engines that integrate generative AI do produce summaries.

### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
From Bradley Silver in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/zaXD4Ah5ruMVIr1sbdwMVeYkOIk):

On search, I agree with the concerns Chris raised - but I also wonder whether this is something that can be better clarified in the drafting, versus there being actual disagreement about what that category is intended to cover or not, when it comes to the line between search results and "answers" with citations.

issues.title: "No preference" vs "unknown"
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
### Confirmation

- [x] I have reviewed our [existing issues](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/issues?q=state%3Aopen) and this issue is not present there.
- [x] I have read and understand the [IETF NOTE WELL](https://www.ietf.org/about/note-well/).

### Issue Description

_From @chrisn in [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ai-control/2ZbEx73js_cTQT8mI1Wy6_0ZC_s):_

The "no preference" terminology could be misinterpreted as meaning that a website or content provider does not mind how their content is used (i.e., they don't have a preference either way). This would not be a valid assumption to make. It would be much more accurate to state that the preference is unknown. I recommend that the document aligns on the "allow", "disallow", and "unknown" statuses described in Section 5. This affects various parts of the draft:

* In Section 3, change "This can mean that no preference is stated for a given usage category" to "This can mean that the preference for a given usage category is unknown".

* In Section 3.2, which says "allow, disallow, or no preference"

* In Section 6, I suggest a rephrasing: "For example, the following states a preference to allow AI training (Section 4.2), disallow generative AI training (Section 4.3). The preference for categories other than subsets of these categories is unknown." (This would also fix the repeated "and" and "other" in the existing text.)

* In Section 6.5, "Otherwise, no preference is stated for that category of use" should be "Otherwise, the preference for that category of use is unknown".

* In Section 6.6, "A mapping might then define that no preference is associated with other categories" should be "A mapping might then define the preference associated with other categories is unknown."


### Proposed Resolution

_No response_

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: This seems pretty easy.  It's one of those tricks of English, where "no preference" and "no stated preference" mean something different.  The latter, or "unknown preference" as Chris suggests, is what we should be using.

comments.author: DNStories
comments.body:
I prefer "no preference indicated" or no stated preference to unknown. It signals that the content provider has provided no explicit instruction within the AIPref header.  
It's Farzaneh ... (I changed my name but it doesn't appear!)

comments.author: chrisn
comments.body: The reason I suggest unknown is that would make the rest of the document consistent with section 5, which describes the three potential answers of allow, disallow, and unknown.

Changing the intended status here will make all that possible.

comments.body: Thanks @martinthomson these all look good to me

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: A few suggestions, but this looks good overall.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This document proposes a standardized vocabulary for expressing preferences related to how digital assets are used by automated processing systems.
This vocabulary allows for the creation of structured declarations about restrictions or permissions for use of digital assets by such systems.
The vocabulary is agnostic to the means by which it is conveyed.
```

The middle clause of this second sentence seems a little rough to me.  Perhaps:

```suggestion
The terms defined by the vocabulary can be used to describe, in a standardized way, the types of uses that a declaring party may wish to explicitly restrict or allow.
Preferences are then expressed as a grant or denial of permission concerning each of the types of use defined in the vocabulary.
This ensures that preferences can be communicated, processed, and stored in a consistent and interoperable manner.
```

(I'm moving to sentence-per-line as much as possible so that these sorts of changes are easier to manage. The underlying format doesn't really care what we do, so I'm OK with anything really.)

```suggestion
The vocabulary is neutral to the technical details of how systems act on preferences.
It is designed to ensure that preference information can be exchanged between different systems and consistently understood.
```

```suggestion
The vocabulary is intended to govern the use of digital assets for the training of AI models and other forms of automated processing.
It does not concern itself with the mechanisms involved in obtaining digital assets (i.e., crawling).
```

Trying to keep sentence length down, that's all.

pulls.title: The abstract model
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
There are a few things here that I'm struggling with, but I'm starting with the basics.

The first is to better define the abstract model.  That is, each category of use has a preference that is either "allow", "disallow", or "unstated".

The next is to give us more space for category definitions.  Right now, these are pretty short, but we'll need to say more.  I've not modified text much, but I've added notes about AI and GenAI being subsets of the preceding categories.

There is also new text on what it means to receive more specific instructions.  The old text was not clear about the ways in which things might be made more specific.  I've expanded this to note the two ways:

1. that the vocabulary might be expanded
2. there might be more specific instructions in agreements between users of assets and other actors that override any general statement that is made

This latter point seems to be a continual point of confusion in discussions thus far, so I'm not claiming that this addresses those concerns yet.  Still, it seemed necessary to get at least a basic statement in place.

I've moved a few things around as well, to get things into a better flow.  In preparation for adding more text on exemplary serialization, search, inference, and other such things.

pulls.title: Define an exemplary format
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
As discussed, we want to define a recommended format.  This executes on that.  It uses Structured Fields, which will ensure that we have a very easy translation to HTTP fields.  It also fits neatly into the other formats we are considering.

There are some interesting implications that are worth highlighting. The text I've added goes into some of that in more detail, but just to list them for visibility:

* This is a sequence of bytes, not a string.  That has implications for how it is included in some formats, but as RFC 9651 limits its syntax to a pretty small subset of the ASCII range, this is mostly just a theoretical consideration, not a practical one.

* Parsing errors in RFC 9651 means that you lose everything.  No preference survives.  That means that authoring errors have consequences.  This is an artifact of the format being more of a computer-to-computer language, rather than being tolerant of human error.  I'm not thrilled with this, but recognize the trade-off involved.

* Repeated keys mean that only the last one is taken.  Again, not thrilled with this, but think that the trade is tolerable.

* Labels are lowercase only.  A lot of the list traffic has started to use "AI=whatever"; RFC 9651 doesn't let us shout.  I think that this is fine, but it's another minor ding.

* Some patterns of use that might be natural are invalid.  For instance, spaces around the "=" is invalid, so "ai = n" would result in a parsing error and no preference being registered.

Closes #8.

reviews.body:

comments.body:
Hm, Unicode string has a definition that doesn't match what I wanted: https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode16.0.0/core-spec/chapter-3/#G32765

This is a description of the restrictions in the RFC 9651 format, which I would suggest we not mess with.  It creates the possibility of having things with `*` in it, but that's not something I would endorse.  Like you, I think that `*` is confusing.  As is the mixing of `_` and `-`.

reviews.body:
I agree that most edits improve the text, but I think the edits to the last para do not work. I have a number of issues with the new language, but the most important is that where the old language implied that this is intended to work in both contexts the new language says that it is "**intended to work** in contexts where such preferences result in legal obligations" and then continues that "The vocabulary **can be used** in contexts where there is no specific legal protections". To me this somehow implies a hierarchy and I do not think that is correct.

for now I would suggest reverting to the previous language here (I also do not think that we need to purge the document of all mentions of Text and Data Mining. This is an established legal concept in a number of different jurisdictions that applies to the types of uses for which we develop this vocabulary and we cannot make it go away by simply not mentioning TDM.

comments.body:
I find this paragraph a little difficult to parse. It _feels_ like the first sentence contradicts the third.

Maybe something more like:

The vocabulary is intended to work both in contexts where such preferences result in legal obligations and in contexts where there are no specific legal protections. In contexts with resulting legal obligations, this might include rights reservations made by rightholders in jurisdictions with conditional exceptions on copyright. In contexts where there are no specific legal protections, preferences can be made without prejudice to applicable laws and the applicability of exceptions and limitations to copyright.

pulls.title: Removed reference to origin of TDM definition
pulls.author: paul2keller
pulls.body:
This pull request proposes to leave the definition of TDM unchanged, but removes the explicit reference that this is based on EU law. This is part based on a review of existing legal definitions of TDM in other jurisdictions that have TDM exceptions in ether copyright law: 

The UK does not have a proper definition in the law itself, but the UK government provides on as part of its Guidance on Exceptions to copyright which is very similar to the EU definition: 

"Text and data mining is the use of automated analytical techniques to analyse text and data for patterns, trends and other useful information."

The other two jurisdictions with TDM exceptions that I am aware of (Singapore and Japan) do not use the term TDM. Instead they anchor the exceptions on “computational data analysis” (SG) or “data analysis (JP). 

Given this it seems sensible to keep the definition of TDM as unchanged.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
Background and links to the relevant passages the copyright legislation of the above mentioned jurisdictions: 

### 🇪🇺 European Union:

In the EU the definition is laid down [in Article 2(2) of the Copyright in the Digital Single Market Directive](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/dir/2019/790/oj/eng#art_2):

> ‘text and data mining’ means any automated analytical technique aimed at analysing text and data in digital form in order to generate information which includes but is not limited to patterns, trends and correlations.
> 

### 🇬🇧 United Kingdom

The UK does not have a proper defintion in the law, but the UK government provides on as part of its [Guidance on Exceptions to copyright](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/exceptions-to-copyright):

> Text and data mining is the use of automated analytical techniques to analyse text and data for patterns, trends and other useful information.
> 

The [actual TDM exception in UK law](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1988/48/section/29A) specifies that it is not an infringement of copyright to "carry out a computational analysis of anything recorded in the work”

### 🇸🇬 Singapore (computational data analysis)

Singapore does not have a definition of TDM instead it defines the equivalent term “Computational data analysis” [in section 244 of its copyright code](https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/P15-P28-):

> “computational data analysis”, in relation to a work or a recording of a protected performance, includes 
(a)	using a computer program to identify, extract and analyse information or data from the work or recording; and
(b)	using the work or recording as an example of a type of information or data to improve the functioning of a computer program in relation to that type of information or data.
> 

### 🇯🇵 Japan (data analysis)

Japan does not have an explicit definition. [Here is the relevant text in Article 30-4](https://www.cric.or.jp/english/clj/cl2.html) is referred to as the Japanese TDM exception (emphasis mine):

> It is permissible to exploit a work, in any way and to the extent considered necessary, in any of the following cases, or in any other case in which it is not a person's purpose to personally enjoy or cause another person to enjoy the thoughts or sentiments expressed in that work; provided, however, that this does not apply if the action would unreasonably prejudice the interests of the copyright owner in light of the nature or purpose of the work or the circumstances of its exploitation:
> 
> 
> (i)　if it is done for use in testing to develop or put into practical use technology that is connected with the recording of sounds or visuals of a work or other such exploitation;
> 
> (ii)　**if it is done for use in data analysis (meaning the extraction, comparison, classification, or other statistical analysis of the constituent language, sounds, images, or other elemental data from a large number of works or a large volume of other such data**; the same applies in Article 47-5, paragraph (1), item (ii));

pulls.title: Add a description of how the model is interrogated
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is stacked on top of #26.  It just shows the incremental change.  (If it is accepted and #26 is not, we'll lose it.  Be careful.)

Rather than describe how defaults apply as part of the processing algorithm, I've made that part of how the model is consulted.  This doesn't have any functional impact in this case; the result is the same either way.

The main decision this makes is about the order in which things apply:

1. within a single statement, the most-specific statement applies (i.e., `genai` overrides `ai`)
2. across multiple statements, the least-permissive statement of preference applies (i.e., `n` overrides `y`)

We'll need to discuss which model we want to follow and be deliberate about it.

An example should help.  Consider two statements of preference that include no preference for nested categories: `ai=n` and `genai=y`.

In the proposed approach, the more general answer from the first statement fills in an answer for the `genai` category.  That's the model that this change adopts.  The final, combined answer for `genai` is determined by the `ai=n` preference because the value from that statement is taken first and a disallow preference overrides an allow preference (absent other information; see the text).

In an alternative model, preferences could be combined before resolving any inherited preferences.  That is, items 1 and 2 above are swapped to:

1. across multiple statements, the least permissive statement of preference for each category is selected
2. then any category without an assigned preference inherits the preference of any less-specific category

In that case, we'd be saying that `ai=n` leaves `genai` unspecified deliberately to allow another preference to set `genai=y` if they prefer.  Only if no other entity expresses a preference, does the implied `genai=n` apply.  In that model, we'd be assuming that the entity that sets `ai=n` knows about `genai` and chooses to defer to others on what the preference is.

I personally dislike the alternative.  It makes any vocabulary extension fraught with issues.  Consider that an extension we define later might carve out space for a new specialized usage (like `inference`, if we were to define that in three years time, or `commercial` or anything else we might defer).  That would put an unexpected hole in any established preference.  Anyone who previously said no to a class of usage could have that preference overridden for that specialized usage.

Structuring the document this way allows us to make a decision between these a little more easily than if the "processing" in #26 filled in values for `genai` from the value of `ai`.

Finally, the last decision in the change is that attachment mechanisms can define that one statement can override another.

That opens the possibility of us choosing to have the HTTP header override robots.txt or even having content metadata override any other preferences.  If we find that this isn't needed, that's fine, but I understand that this is still on the table.  Including it cost me little effort; removing it would be equally easy.

pulls.title: Revise intent statement
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This was the hardest part of #31 and I think we could make this text clearer.  It is a bit too dense, even with what I'm proposing, but I hope that it's an improvement.

This is a version of the text provided by Timid Robot in https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/31#discussion_r2100758813 with some additional edits, particularly the last sentence, where I think we need to be clear that:

1. This shouldn't prejudice decisions about other rights outside of the meaning of the preference itself.
2. The no prejudice piece applies even if the preferencing has legal effect, outside of the direct and obvious legal effect itself.
3. This isn't necessarily exclusively about copyright.  People have privacy rights over content that still apply, even if the preferences admit the possibility of use.

I think that this maintains the intent of the original, but I will admit that the original is dense enough that I might have lost some of the intent.

pulls.title: IANA registry
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
(Again, this is based on #26; merge this and nothing happens unless you also merge #26.)

This enacts the suggested approach for vocabulary extensions I described in #38.

Still, this was particularly tricky to get the wording even remotely in the space I wanted and I'm not sure whether I got there.  Input on this would be appreciated.

Basically, I'm conflicted on this.  Using Specification Required gives some flexibility for the process to recognize emerging labels without a lot of procedural overhead, but it seems like this is angling toward IETF Review as the operative policy.  Should we face facts and just go straight for IETF Review?  That would allow the advice to be a little more streamlined, because we'd be able to rely on the standards process to iron out the kinks.

There's also the option to pair IETF Review with IESG Approval, which means "get an RFC" or "convince an IETF AD".  That almost amounts to the same thing in practice (if you can convince an AD of something, one of those things is publishing an RFC.  Though the RFC still requires IETF consensus, so it's a somewhat higher bar, but only "somewhat" given how careful most ADs are).

In any case, this seemed like a reasonable starting point for a discussion, which is always easier when there is something concrete to discuss.

The IETF policy is that people participate as individuals, which means that we do not generally list affiliation when it comes to acknowledgments.  There's a carve-out for authorship and a few other things, but this is how we generally operate.

The formatting ensures that people can use their actual name.  Not a problem for these all-ASCII names, but it might end up being a problem later.

I've also sorted the list (by first name, which is my preferred approach once we have to deal with people who put family names first and all that).
