pulls.title: A reframing of search
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
As discussed on the list recently.

This does not include Brad's suggestion of "for the exclusive purpose of".  That is an important clarification, but I think we need to address that separately.  That is, we need to recognize that what we conceive of as "search" applications are more complicated than a simple index that is used to locate stuff.  We need commentary that explains that a single application can embody multiple usage categories and that use of assets for each of those aspects can have separate rules.  This isn't necessarily how those applications are built today[^1], but that's not necessarily a constraint on what we do.

[^1]: I am reminded of the concept of a "data lake", which has no distinction about where data has come from, the purpose for which it was obtained, or anything along those lines, making compliance with data protection regulation impossible.  The analogy here is with respect to use of assets for multiple purposes, without distinction.  For data lakes, the introduction of things like GDPR helped application developers build discipline about how they obtain and label personal information; perhaps this requires a similar shift, albeit one that affects a smaller set of people.

pulls.title: robots.txt attachment: make path segment mandatory
pulls.author: bnewbold
pulls.body:
This updates the draft text to make the path segment mandatory instead of optional. The motivation is to make the `Content-Usage` directive read more clearly like the `Allow`/`Disallow` directives, and generally make robots.txt files more legible and understandable to humans (whether they have prior experience with robots.txt or not). This should have almost no impact on actual behavior or what preferences can be expressed. The trade-off is that every line will have two additional bytes for the case of "all paths", and that seems like a reasonable trade off for legibility.

A secondary benefit is that implementation becomes marginally easier: code will know there is always a leading path segment. While optional fields are common in protocols, it is more common to have trailing fields be optional, not leading fields. The current text *is* unambiguous about how to detect whether there is a path segment or not (if there is a leading `/` character), but this makes things just a bit easier to implement correctly.

I think this would be an improvement on the syntax and it would be great to get it in. However, I do want to prioritize moving work forward, and think this improvement is not worth holding things up.

comments.author: bnewbold
comments.body: To expand on thinking of this a bit more: I suspect if the path is optional, it will be common to not include it, and set overall preferences for entire websites, perhaps by group (eg, by named crawler). If that is a common pattern, it is possible for developers, hosts, and crawlers to never encounter a line with a path segment, and make incorrect assumptions about allowed syntax.

```suggestion
{{usage}} explains how to use AI Preferences in a data processing application,
and {{format}} describes a way to serialize preferences into a string.
{{consulting}} describes an algorithm for determining the value of a specific preference.
```
Just wrapping, so that future changes are easier to manage.

```suggestion
{{ATTACH}} defines mechanisms to associate preferences with assets.
Other means of association might be defined separately in the future.
```

pulls.title: A more verbose search definition
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This keeps the short definition, but it expands it considerably to cover what seems to be the emerging perspective on the list.

This aims to do three things:

1. Narrow the definition to cover those cases that drive traffic to the original location of assets.

2. Ensure that this allows the use of AI in search applications, so that search preferences override AI use preferences.

3. To ensure that AI overviews, which act as a substitute for visiting the site, are excluded.

Obviously, there will continue to be things on the line.  The draft has text addressing the question of ambiguity.  As has been noted, the law has far better tools for managing that than technical specifications... if there is a dispute, that is.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This includes the use of titles or excerpts from assets
that are used to help users select between multiple candidate options.

Preferences for the Search category apply to those parts of applications
that provide search capabilities,
regardless of what other preferences are expressed.
```

```suggestion
Search applications can be complex 
and may serve multiple purposes.
```

```suggestion
Only those parts of applications that direct users to the location of an asset
are included in this category of use.
```

pulls.title: Expand on the preference overriding text
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is a light reworking of a proposal from Lila Bailey on the list.

The value of this is that it is far more comprehensive than the previous text, which was directionally helpful, but not thorough enough to give the right impression.  Having more text is often something to avoid, but in this case it seems like it is adding a lot of value in terms of making the *preferences* thing far clearer.

My only concern here -- which is a very minor one -- is that this looks almost exclusively at the overriding of preferences to disallow.  I couldn't come up with a convincing example of a decision to ignore express permission.

Closes #99.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: The arrow of time is ever forward; feedback suggests that this is an improvement, even if this isn't necessarily a final state for this text.
I suspect 'ignore' would work better than 'override' here and elsewhere.

```suggestion

```

```suggestion

```

pulls.title: Define AI and AI Training
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is a less hurried version of what I threw together during the sessions on Monday morning of the IETF meeting.

This draws on many definitions, primarily the one from Luciano Floridi in his commentary about the discussions between the EU and US: https://doi.org/10.1007/s13347-023-00690-z

That document includes a number of citations to legal definitions and other definitional work, including by the OECD, that were influential in coming to a definition.  I found a number of other sources, including the ITU definition mentioned in #100 (thanks to @taddhar for sharing that).

The definitions of AI Training and Machine Learning are a synthesis of much longer definitions by c3.ai and IBM, primarily. https://c3.ai/glossary/data-science/model-training/ https://www.ibm.com/think/topics/machine-learning

Closes #100.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: In general this looks like a substantial improvement to me. I made one suggested in the last part (alternatively we could also consider to remove the final sentence with the examples, that would probably be cleaner and i do not really see the need for going into this level of detail for a second order definition.

Paul's suggestion is to make this much shorter (which I find myself agreeing with the more I stare at it).

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  that, for a given set of human-defined objectives,
  learns from data to generate outputs
  such as content, predictions, recommendations, or decisions.
```

This is a variation of a suggestion from Jo Levy.  It drops the "new" that was proposed ("new content") because I can't see how that qualification helps and it potentially excludes rewriting, translation, summarization, and other generation tasks.

```suggestion
: Machine Learning refers to processing data
```

"refers to process of" is missing a "the", but it could be even shorter.


comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
I think we are at risk of loosing substantial safeguards here.We need to have explicit language that there will be situations in which legal regimes override any preferences (the most concrete example, although not the best because Eurocentrism concerns) is the TDM exception for scientific research in Article 3 the EU copyright directive. 

I think the approach to combine (or at least move closer to each other) the legal section and this one makes a lot of sense. And as a reminder there is one other section in the doc that also deals with this issue, that is the 2nd para of the `#introduction` section:

> The vocabulary is intended to be used in jurisdictions where expressing preferences results in legal obligations, as well as where there are no associated legal obligations. In either case, expressing preferences is without prejudice to applicable laws, including the applicability of exceptions and limitations to copyright.

comments.author: Jo-Levy
comments.body: Some of the new language --and some of the old language-- are normatively charged.  I propose that, to the extent these changes are incorporated, "an unconditional right" be revised to "a right"  and "never" be changed to "not".  For the same reason,  I suggest, throughout the text of the spec and document, to change the words "respect" and "ignored" to "followed" and "not followed."  Plus, as the tech spec and documents are directed at technology, not people,  "respect" and "ignored" are anthropomorphic.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: I've moved applicability/legal effect up; it likely needs some editorial adjustment.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Closing in favour of #118.

```suggestion
## Enforcement

This specification does not provide any enforcement mechanism,
and conformance to it does not encompass whether
preferences are actually respected during data processing.

Other mechanisms
-- technical, legal, or otherwise --
might enforce stated preferences.
As such they will determine the consequences for ignoring a stated preference.
Preferences do not imply control, either in the positive or negative.
For example, a stated preference allowing a use does not
(on its own) imply an unconditional right to use it for that purpose;
likewise, a stated preference disallowing a use does not
(on its own) mean that the content can never be used for that purpose.
```

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: This is reasonable.  There's a fair bit of overlap between this and the `#legal` section much lower down.  We probably need to think about reconciling those.  Is there anything in there that would make sense to move up here?

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: Jo Levy mentioned some tweaks that alter the language here.  I'm merely relaying that.  Paul's concerns are more substantive here.

comments.body:
```suggestion
(on its own) mean that the content cannot be used for that purpose.
```

```suggestion
As such they will determine the consequences for following or not following a stated preference.
```

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body:
So there is definitely some overlap here with these two sections.

I think that this could be one section.  Though there are a few things being said here:

1. These are just preferences.
2. However, a statement of preferences can activate laws depending on context.
3. The categories are simple, broad, and therefore will have ambiguities as they are applied to real applications.
4. People who use assets need to take responsibility for that use.
5. (what you removed) There are cases where preferences might not be followed.

The text you added only really covers points 1 and 2.

comments.body: This is probably most redundant, but there is still a useful point: how a category applies to a given application could be a judgment call and that might vary between jurisdictions (if there is a legal effect).

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
I have taken a close look at the changes proposed in this PR and I do not think that we should go down this route (other than that still think it is a good idea to consolidate the the two sections into one). The main change i am objecting here is that the new version (especially way the examples are phrased) quite substantially narrows the safeguards to cases explicitly recognized in law. This collapses the wider discretionary space acknowledged in the current draft—where law, established practice, or societal values can justify overriding preferences—into a much narrower one defined only by explicit legal permission.

> This is turning out to be a difficult needle to successfully thread. As with other genuine attempts to improve the text, this is helpful. I just don't know what razor to apply to decide which is best.

yes this is tricky. for me there are two aspects where I would consider this to preserve important elements of the original language we had before attempts to merge the two sections: 

1. the very unambiguous `MAY` in "A data processor MAY choose to respect preferences that is has discovered" that for me is a very important signal that we are talking about "preferences" that in itself do not have legal effect, and 
2. the "could ignore a preference" wording in the examples, that in #118 in some of the examples has changed into "might be allowed by a legal system" which implies that absent an explicit legal authorization such the preference must be followed (at which point is ceases to be a "mere" preference).

reviews.body: This is turning out to be a difficult needle to successfully thread.  As with other genuine attempts to improve the text, this is helpful.  I just don't know what razor to apply to decide which is best.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Because enforcement is not provided by this specification,
the consequences of ignoring preferences may vary
depending upon how a given legal jurisdiction recognizes preferences;
see {{applicability}}.
```

A list of two might just be better as a sentence:

```suggestion
discovered, according to
an understanding of how the asset is used,
how that usage corresponds to the usage categories
where preferences have been expressed,
and the applicable legal context.
```
I think that I prefer Mark's take on this list of things, both the framing and the "might be allowed by a legal system to ignore a preference" language.

you mean replacing lines 198 and 199 with: 

> For example, a legal system might require adherence to stated preferences,
but allow them to be ignored for specified purposes, such as:
And probably the other tweaks made to each of the list items.  I know it's almost redundant, but I've learned that spending the extra words on being extra precise is often necessary.

I prefer @paul2keller s proposed language insofar as it doesn't refer to a legal system that allows ignoring a certain preference. By default, anything that is not expressly prohibited by a legal system is allowed. Therefore, a legal system rarely is explicit in what it allows. Consequently, "a legal system might ... allow them to be ignored" could create misunderstandings where people might read this as requiring an explicit legal provision that allows somebody to ignore a stated preference. In reality, unless a legal system explicitly requires somebody to _respect_ a stated preference, ignoring it is allowed.

```suggestion
the consequences of ignoring preferences could vary
```

```suggestion
depending upon how a given legal jurisdiction recognizes preferences.
```

```suggestion
An entity that receives usage preferences MAY choose to respect
those preferences it has discovered, according to
```

pulls.title: AI Output and Search categories
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is the output of the informali, impromptu design team that was formed during the last day of meetings.  This attempts to synthesize ideas from numerous sources, including various email threads on the mailing list, drafts shared (in particular
draft-madhavan-aipref-displaybasedpref) and some ideas that were floating around.

This concentrates on system outputs and aims to primarily address concerns about substitutive use.  That is, the potential for AI to generate content that is different from source material, but which might replace it.

We did not include some of the concepts that were in draft-madhavan-aipref-displaybasedpref about limiting output size and so forth, but recognize that those might make good extensions at a later time.  Those will depend on specific formats (text lengths for text, snippet duration for audio or video, etc..) and we concluded that we want to concentrate on the core concept.

This is a less flexible version of the thing that was presented.  Rather than having separate conditions of use attached to a permission grant, one for linking back and another for requiring direct quoting rather than paraphrasing or summarizing.  These too might need further refinement in future.  For example, we talked about how certain formats might be able to identify which content (text, time, whatever) is OK to quote and which is not.

This does not attempt to address the new problem this raises, which is that indicating that you would like these new categories to be allowed in practice also means that you need to say the same for AI training. That's not a problem this is attempting to solve.  We'll need to do that in some other way.
